In 2014, the iphone 6 sold 74.5 million phones during the December quarter. The release of the iphone 6s saw record sales, but there is reason to believe this trend did not continue. Sales are strong in emerging markets but apple cut back on orders from parts suppliers, signaling sales might not be as strong as apple had hoped. Additionally, the 6s did not have enough changes to motivate some users to upgrade their phones. The growth in sales in countries like China makes it possible that apple will break the 75 million sales record. However, it is unlikely due to the reasons stated above.

Apple sold 74.47 million units Q1 2015. It seems likely that it will beat this number, (as Tim Cook has stressed repeatedly), but not by very much. Analysts seem to thinking something like 75-76 million.

For:
- Earlier expectations of 85 mil has been revised down. 
- China market is still largely underpenetrated. 
- US consumer sentiment is stronger and Apple's innvoative new trade-in programme in US could see more upgraders.

The 6S clearly did not do as well as as the 6 launch, but older models also continued to sell at a lower price point. I suspect US iPhone sales will decline compared to the quarter last year, but global sales will more than make up the difference. Tim Cook said in October that they would beat the previous year. If this outlook changed as the quarter went on, I'm sure they made adjustments to have a positive story. I don't think they will beat 75 MM by that many units though.

I tried the following thought experiment. On 26th of October, Tim Cook has indicated that he expected iPhones sales to be higher this quarter than the 2015Q1 (74.47M). “We believe that iPhone will grow in Q1” “Is it revenue? I was making a revenue statement but units are also, yes we expect units to be up as well.” (Tim Cook quotes from conference call transcripts on SeekingAlpha). Tim Cook does not make many of these forward looking statements and he does not strike me as the person to make these type of forecasts lightly.  On the 26th of October, Tim Cook most likely knew the amount of iPhones sold up to 26th October (about 1/3 of the 2016Q1). The question is how many iPhone sold up to that time would him make comfortable expecting overall growth? I asked myself what number I would be comfortable with even if I had more information than I have.  (He will have better data and a clear sales pattern in mind) I would most likely err on the side of caution. Particularly because that was a month after the introduction of the 6S and 6SPlus. If one thinks of a Sales number for October that would make him comfortable, it is easy to get a lowerbound estimate for the full quarter.

I believe it is fairly likely that Apple will sell more than 75 million iPhones in its December quarter. With Apple's launch of the new iPhone 6s and 6s Plus, consumers have more options for products to purchase, and its rollout of new pricing and financing plans will help boost sales numbers as well. The largest doubts, in my mind, come from the fact that the new 6s and 6s Plus are only marginal improvements over their prior iterations (and thus seem like they will be less popular than an overhauled product would be). It would also be interesting to get more data (although I wasn't able to find much information more specific than this: http://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/mobile-phones/11812322/smartphone-sales-in-china-fall-says-gartner.html) on how sales might be impacted by the economic slowdown in China, a huge market for Apple's iPhone products.

Will Apple Sell More than 75M iPhones in the December Quarter?

1.	Rate of growth decelerating. Total unit volume growth in 2014 v 2013 was 12.6% compared to 2011 v 2010 growth of 80.8%.  
2.	Largest market is China, China is decelerating based on the market action of the Chinese stock market. 
3.	Q1 has become, since 2012 the largest quarter of the year representing more than 30% of annual volume and Q4 has since 2012 has represented approximately 22 â€“ 23% of annual unit volume. If this trend continues the volume estimate for Q4 would be approximately 52M units.
4.	The iPhone 6 was released in September of 2014 which lead to a significant increase in volume in the subsequent quarters, in fact Q1 2015 is the largest volume quarter ever recorded. To replicate that volume in the same year would require an additional 75M new iPhone users rather than the usual replacement cycle which would have occurred in or about Q1 2015. 
5.	The 6S released in September 2015 will probably also lead to a significant increase in volume however to reach 75M units would be a 190% increase in unit volume over the same quarter in 2014 and a 157% increase over Q3 2015 both of which are increases far greater than in any previous quarter.

I update my earlier (79%) forecast substantially after a bit more research. 
- Based on my relative optimistic view compared to other forecasters around here my initial probability seems too low.
- Some forecasters here whom have taken a serious crack at answering this question in different ways and by putting some numbers on this all get higher than 75 mln. 
- Cook is very confident that Apple will sell more than last year (74.5) and Mr. Cook is generally a cautious man when it comes to make any 'exact' forecasts. But in the Analyst Conference Call he is willing to say this. Cook has insight to the Chines data relative to other countries. YoY growth in China has been around 100%. Hard to get exact numbers but let's say sales last quarter (last year) in China were 1/3 of 75 or 25 mln and grow to 40 mln units (still well below 100%) (1/3 is conservative estimate based on suggestions that iPhone Sales in China have now surpassed US). That means that sales in other countries would have to drop from 50 to 35 mln. That seems farfetched. 
- Supporting the above China's middle class is expected to grow ten fold in the next five years.
- Supporting the above Alibaba Single Day Sales have seen a dramatic increase.
- I cannot find the Credit Suisse report itself and the articles on it are pretty vague. Apart from my earlier comment It would make sense that Apple slashes its orders most phones for this quarter have already been made and next quarter sales are always lower.

It will be close but I think they will make it. Professional analysts predict just above 75 mln and the indies higher. Total average 78 mln. (over the years analyst prediction in aggregate seem to have become a bit more reliable).
- I don't believe the 10% slash story with some suppliers. In the past these stories have always proven not to have any relation with actual sales.
- The law of large numbers argument is only put forward by people who do not seem to understand what the law of large numbers actually is about. 
- There may be some cannibalism from the new products (Apple Watch, Apple TV, iPad Pro) but that will be off-set by a halo effect of new Apple users (increasing market share in PC's etc).
- The Chinese market is becoming increasingly important in sales and particularly US based investors and analysts seem to have difficulty to understand its sheer size and potential and the love Chinese Apple users seem to feel for their iPhones). 
- The new annual upgrading program seems hugely popular which may help increase the US numbers
- The iPhone 6S has become available in many more countries and much faster than with previous releases
- Economies are recovering a bit allowing more consumers to treat themselves after the tougher years
- Apple's new strategy in India might also start to take off. 
- Only twenty percent of current iPhone owners have upgraded and so there is a large potential there for new phones as iPhone users hardly switch.

- On the downside consumer with less to spend may hold off for the smaller iPhone which is rumoured to appear next year. 
- I also may be biased as I own Apple shares, and have long ago decided that life's too short to use Microsoft (or Android) based products.

I was initially drawn into the doubt that Apple would not reach the 75m mark, but found a few issues with the Pacific Crest analysis. Firstly, it's just one analysis of the situation from a firm with a track record that I can't find out. The analysis also seems to be focused on the 6S' sales, and reading over my previous forecast, I read how with the 6 now being $100 cheaper, sales growth won't just come from the 6S. 
More importantly with the analysis, there wasn't as much detail as I'd have liked. Assuming that the excerpts which have been published in articles like this (http://www.businessinsider.com.au/iphone-6s-sales-disappointing-pacific-crest-2015-10), which have been mentioned by quite a few others before me, are all that he's said on this topic and is all the detail that he goes into, then it has to be questioned what Apple's initial "component orders" or "expectations" were. It's all relative; so if Apple's initial expectations and component orders were for iPhone sales of say 80m, then below expectations or "disappointing sales" might not mean sales will fall below 75m. His sources might have been similarly vague about describing sales. How does he calculate an estimate of 67m units?
In terms of what he says about fewer stores selling out of iPhones, as I recall, last year's iPhone release had supply issues considering demand beat expectations (quick search gives 71.5m) and also issues with manufacturing the 6 Plus' larger screen.
On the final point, that “almost all carriers surveyed indicated that iPhone 6s sales were down y/y, compared to the iPhone 6.”, I'm assuming he's referring to US carriers. Now couldn't it be possible that people just aren't buying from carriers and are waiting for the sim-free (unlocked) iPhone? (which apparently just started production http://appleinsider.com/articles/15/10/08/apple-starts-sales-of-sim-free-iphone-6s-6s-plus-handsets)
This article goes over some of the points raised here and in my previous forecast: http://www.fool.com/investing/general/2015/10/12/the-iphone-sales-slump-doomsayers-are-forgetting-t.aspx
Overall, its probably still a bit early to say that the 75m mark won't be reached since many countries haven't even started selling iPhones yet, but just in case all my assumptions are wrong, there's a decrease in my forecast.
